journal-title-group.journal-title: The Journal of Financial and Quantitative Analysis

title-group.article-title: To Pay or Be Paid? The Impact of Taker Fees and Order Flow Inducements on Trading Costs in U.S. Options Markets

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2016 Michael G. Foster School of Business, University of Washington

abstract.p: Consistent with prior literature, we find that average relative effective spreads are higher for venues that pay for order flow (PFOF) than for venues utilizing the maker-taker (MT) model. This relation becomes more nuanced when liquidity fees are incorporated into liquidity cost measures. For the majority of options, PFOF venues offer lower average liquidity costs net of taker fees. Net liquidity costs for the high-priced options, however, are lower for MT venues. Overall, our results suggest that the inclusion of fees and rebates can rationalize the routing of most, but not all, marketable orders to PFOF venues.

p.mixed-citation: the Sept. 2010 GETCO letter to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) (http://goo.gl/7Sxe0e).
SEC Release 34-61902, "Proposed Amendments to Rule 610 of Regulation NMS," Apr. 14, 2010.

July 17, 2008, letter from the SIFMA Equity Options Trading Committee to the U.S. Options Exchanges.
